title-group.article-title: Diagnostic value of Serum Amyloid A (SAA) in HIV-associated pulmonary infections and its correlation with inflammatory markers

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/01nnwyz44grid.470110.30000 0004 1770 0943Department of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, No 2901, Caolang Road, Jinshan District, Shanghai, 201508 China

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To evaluate the impact of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection on serum amyloid A (SAA) levels in acute pulmonary infections and assess correlations between SAA and other inflammatory markers in HIV-associated pneumonia.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: In this retrospective case-control study, 48 HIV-positive patients with pulmonary infections (HIV group) and 55 age-matched HIV-negative controls (control group) were enrolled from Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center (2021.5–2025.5). Demographic, hospitalization duration and laboratory parameters - including SAA, white blood cell count (WBC), C-reactive protein (CRP), procalcitonin (PCT), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), platelet count (PLT), CD4+ T cell count, and absolute lymphocyte count(ALC) - were systematically collected from both patient cohorts. For intergroup comparisons, the Mann-Whitney U test was employed, while Spearman’s rank correlation analysis was conducted to assess biomarker associations within the HIV-positive subgroup.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Among 103 patients, the HIV group had higher male predominance (83.3% vs. 54.5%, P = 0.02) and lower CD4+ T cell count (215.17 vs. 443.41 cells/µL, P < 0.05). SAA (178.39 vs. 122.93 mg/L, P = 0.032), CRP (64.27 vs. 37.07 mg/L, P = 0.031), LDH (310.65 vs. 235.96 U/L, P = 0.024), and hospitalization duration (16.83 vs. 13.05 days, P = 0.013) were significantly elevated in HIV patients. SAA correlated positively with CRP (r = 0.4807), PCT (r = 0.3554), LDH (r = 0.3564), and PLT (r = 0.3094) (P < 0.05 for all).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Patients with HIV-associated pulmonary infections exhibited significantly elevated levels of SAA, CRP, and LDH, along with prolonged hospital stays, compared to non-HIV-infected individuals. These findings suggest that HIV infection amplifies systemic inflammatory responses, potentially contributing to extended hospitalization. The robust correlations between SAA and other biomarkers (including CRP, PCT, LDH, PLT) highlight its potential as a key component in early diagnostic panels for HIV-associated pulmonary infections.

funding-source.institution: The Department-level Project of Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center
Shanghai Science and Technology Innovation Action Plan

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Serum amyloid A (SAA), a sensitive acute-phase reactant, surges within 24–36 h post-infection or trauma, reflecting underlying inflammation [1]. Notably, sustained inflammation or chronic pathological stimulation may result in prolonged elevation of SAA levels.While antiretroviral therapy (ART) has transformed HIV into a chronic condition [2, 3], chronic immune activation and sustained inflammation are central pathological features of HIV infection [4, 5]. This chronic inflammatory state not only drives long-term complications in people with HIV, but may also impair their ability to mount effective immune defenses against subsequent lung infections.

Given this context, studying how HIV infection alters acute inflammatory responses in pulmonary infections is clinically crucial. While SAA serves as a sensitive biomarker, its diagnostic role in HIV-associated pulmonary infections and relationship with other inflammatory markers remain unclear. We therefore analyzed clinical data from HIV-positive and HIV-negative patients with pneumonia (2021.5–2025.5) to: (1) Assess how HIV infection status affects acute-phase SAA levels in pulmonary infection patients; (2) Investigating the correlation between SAA and key inflammatory biomarkers (such as C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, white blood cell count, etc.) in HIV-associated pulmonary infections. This study aims to investigate the correlation between serum amyloid A (SAA) and other inflammatory biomarkers in HIV-positive patients with pulmonary infections. These findings will enhance our understanding of inflammatory patterns in this population and offer new insights for clinical diagnosis and inflammation monitoring.

sec.title: General data
sec.p: This study enrolled 48 HIV-positive patients with pulmonary infections treated at Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center’s Respiratory Medicine Department (2021.5-2025.5). The cohort comprised 40 males and 8 females, with a mean age of 55.44 ± 14.91 years. Inclusion criteria: (1) Age >18 years; (2) Confirmed pulmonary infection diagnosis; (3) HIV-positive status verified through standardized testing or prior diagnosis with documented long-term antiviral therapy; (4) Complete inflammatory marker panel (including SAA) available.Exclusion criteria: incomplete data or concurrent extrapulmonary infections.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: We retrospectively analyzed demographic and clinical data from both patient groups, capturing gender, age, smoking status, and key comorbidities (hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and malignancies). Admission laboratory profiles (≤ 24 h) encompassed SAA, C-reactive protein (CRP), procalcitonin (PCT), white blood cell count(WBC), platelet count(PLT), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), CD4+ T cell count, and Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. Clinical management data (oxygen therapy requirements) and outcomes (hospital stay duration) were also recorded.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 25.0 (IBM Corp). Between-group comparisons employed the Mann-Whitney U test, and Spearman’s rank correlation assessed relationships among HIV group indicators. A P-value less than 0.05 was considered as significant and all reported P-values are two-sided.

sec.title: Baseline clinical characteristics
sec.p:
The two patient groups showed comparable baseline characteristics, with no significant differences in age, smoking status, oxygen requirement, or comorbidities (P > 0.05).However, a significant gender disparity was observed between groups (P < 0.05), with male patients predominating in the HIV-associated pneumonia cohort (see Table 1). This finding supports prior research conclusions [6, 7].Table 1

sec.title: Comparison of immunological and inflammatory profiles
sec.p:
Patients in the HIV-associated pneumonia group exhibited significantly lower CD4+ T cell count compared to controls (P < 0.05). Notably, inflammatory markers including SAA (t = 2.172), CRP (t = 2.193), and LDH (t = 2.284) were all markedly elevated in the HIV group (P < 0.05). No significant intergroup differences were observed in WBC, ALC, or PCT levels (P > 0.05), (see Table 2).Table 2

sec.title: Correlation analysis of SAA with inflammatory markers in HIV-associated pneumonia
sec.p:
Within the HIV-associated pneumonia cohort, SAA demonstrated significant positive correlations with CRP(r = 0.4807), PCT, (r = 0.3554), LDH(r = 0.3564), and PLT (r = 0.3094)(P < 0.05). However, no significant associations were observed between SAA levels and WBC, CD4+ T cell count, or ALC (all P > 0.05, Fig. 1).Fig. 1
Correlation between SAA levels and inflammatory markers/hospitalization duration in HIV patients with pulmonary infections

As shown in Table 2, Patients in the HIV-associated pneumonia cohort present significantly higher CRP, LDH, and SAA levels than HIV-negative controls. Notably, Fig. 1 further demonstrates a strong correlation between SAA and both CRP and LDH in this population. Together, these findings emphasize the clinical value of these biomarkers’ co-elevation, pointing to a heightened inflammatory burden in patients with HIV-associated pneumonia.

sec.title: Comparison of hospitalization duration between groups
sec.p: Patients with HIV-associated pneumonia exhibited significantly prolonged hospitalization compared to the control group (t = 2.516, P < 0.05, Table 2). However, SAA levels showed no significant correlation with hospital stay duration in this cohort (r = 0.0803, P > 0.05, Fig. 1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The hallmark of HIV infection is progressive CD4+ T lymphocyte depletion, resulting in persistent immunodeficiency that markedly increases susceptibility to opportunistic infections, particularly pulmonary complications [8]. Our findings demonstrate significantly reduced CD4+ T cell count in HIV-infected patients compared to controls (P < 0.05), confirming this immunopathological basis. Notably, even with effective ART, HIV infection sustains chronic immune activation and inflammatory responses involving T cells, B cells, and monocytes, accompanied by elevated pro-inflammatory cytokines including TNF-α, IL-6, and acute-phase proteins such as CRP [9–14]. This persistent inflammatory state not only contributes to non-AIDS-related morbidity and mortality [13, 14], but may also fundamentally alter inflammatory responses to acute secondary infections, such as the pulmonary infections central to this investigation.

As a key acute-phase protein, SAA rapidly escalates following inflammatory stimuli and orchestrates pathogen clearance by recruiting monocytes, neutrophils, dendritic cells, and T cells to sites of inflammation [15]. In chronic inflammatory states, circulating SAA levels—though lower than acute-phase peaks—remain elevated above baseline [16]. However, there is limited research on the dynamic changes of SAA in HIV-infected individuals, particularly in cases of concurrent acute infections (e.g.pulmonary infections), and its diagnostic value remains underexplored [17]. This study therefore addresses a critical gap by examining how chronic HIV infection modulates SAA responsiveness to acute pulmonary inflammation.

A pivotal observation was the markedly higher acute-phase SAA and CRP levels in HIV-positive patients with lung infections versus non-HIV controls (P < 0.05), aligning with Hussbekk et al. [18]. We propose two mechanistic explanations: (1) The compounding effects of chronic immune activation: HIV-induced low-grade inflammation may hypersensitize the immune system to secondary lung infections, amplifying acute-phase protein release; (2) Increased pathogen burden: Immunodeficiency likely predisposes HIV patients to heavier or polymicrobial infections, intensifying the acute-phase response. Moreover, this study demonstrated significantly elevated serum LDH levels in HIV-infected patients compared to controls (P < 0.05), indicating exacerbated tissue damage during concurrent pulmonary infection. Given the well-documented sensitivity of LDH in HIV-associated Pneumocystis pneumonia (PJP) [19], these findings further corroborate that pulmonary infection intensifies histopathological injury in HIV-positive individuals. Together, the data explain the prolonged hospitalization observed in these patients (P < 0.05).

In analyzing inflammatory markers, we observed that SAA levels in HIV patients with pulmonary infections showed significant positive correlations with CRP, PCT, LDH, and PLT. This finding holds important clinical implications. As CRP and SAA are among the most sensitive acute-phase proteins, their concentrations are strongly associated during inflammation, with SAA typically exhibiting a more pronounced increase [20–22]. PCT, driven by endotoxin and cytokines, signals bacterial involvement. LDH serves as a highly sensitive biomarker for tissue injury, reflecting cellular damage with remarkable precision. Beyond its well-known role in hemostasis, emerging evidence highlights PLT as pivotal “first responders” in infection immunity. They actively combat pathogens through direct microbicidal action and by orchestrating immune cell-mediated pathogen clearance [23, 24]. These linkages position SAA as a integrative biomarker reflecting inflammatory intensity, tissue injury, and immune engagement in HIV-lung coinfection. In clinical practice, this approach offers a more effective predictive tool for early diagnosis of acute infections in patients with prolonged chronic infections. Furthermore, the study revealed no significant correlation between SAA levels in HIV patients with pulmonary infections and either CD4+ T cell counts or hospitalization duration. This may be attributed to SAA’s nature as a highly sensitive but short-lived inflammatory marker—it surges rapidly within 24 h of stimulation and declines swiftly post-acute phase. Consequently, while it detects inflammation effectively, it shows minimal association with long-term clinical outcomes such as hospital stay [25, 26].

Beyond acute-phase roles, SAA participates in tissue remodeling, atherosclerosis, and cancer metastasis via receptor interactions and metalloproteinase modulation [1, 27], suggesting potential implications for HIV-related chronic complications—a avenue warranting further study.

This study has several potential limitations. First, as a retrospective analysis, it inherently carries a lower level of evidence compared to prospective studies. Second, although all enrolled patients presented with pulmonary infections, the causative pathogens varied substantially, leading to significant microbial heterogeneity. Third, incomplete viral nucleic acid data in the HIV group precluded further analysis of the relationship between infection and viral load. Fourth, the modest sample size (approximately 50 patients) may limit the robustness of the key findings. Despite these limitations, this study represents the first investigation into the role of SAA in HIV patients with acute lung infections, providing a foundation for future research. Addressing these shortcomings will be a priority in subsequent, more in-depth studies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study establishes that HIV-positive patients with acute lung infections exhibit heightened elevations in SAA, CRP, and LDH versus non-HIV counterparts, indicative of amplified inflammation and tissue damage stemming from chronic immune activation and greater pathogen burden. Crucially, SAA’s correlations with CRP, PCT, LDH, and PLT underscore its utility as a sensitive, integrative inflammatory marker.

By combining SAA—with its rapid kinetic response—and conventional biomarkers (e.g.CRP, PCT), clinicians could improve early diagnosis, severity stratification, and therapeutic monitoring in HIV-associated pneumonias. Future large-scale prospective studies should define SAA’s dynamic profiles, optimal thresholds, and prognostic value in this vulnerable population.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the hospital’s generous support through the hospital-level research project funding.

notes.title: Authors’ contributions
notes.p: R.C. was responsible for data curation, drafting the initial manuscript, editing, and funding acquisition. S. R. and H.T. contributed to conceptualization and methodology development, while Q.W. provided critical revisions to the content. All authors reviewed and approved the final version of the manuscript.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This work was supported by the Department-level Project of Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center (Grant number: No.KY-GW-2025-23) and Shanghai Science and Technology Innovation Action Plan (Grant number: 22Y11901000).

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: Data is provided within the manuscript.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: This research was conducted in compliance with the tenets of the Helsinki Declaration. All stages of the study received ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board of Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center (Approval No.: 2025-S038-03). All patients have provided their informed consent by signing the pan-consent form. Therefore, the Ethics Committee of the Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center granted an exemption from additional informed consent under Article 39 of the ‘Measures for the Ethical Review of Biomedical Research Involving Humans.’

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
